abstract: Google announced it is developing an operating system for personal computers, a direct challenge to Microsoft.
snippet: Google announced it is developing an operating system for personal computers, a direct challenge to Microsoft.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  In a direct challenge to Microsoft, Google announced late Tuesday that it is developing an operating system for PCs that is tied to its Chrome Web browser.

headline.main: Google Plans a PC Operating System
headline.print_headline: Taking Aim at Windows, Google Unveils a PC Operating System

byline.original: By Miguel Helft and Ashlee Vance

abstract: Would you buy a cheap PC with Google software that could only run Web programs, or would you stick with Microsoft Windows?
snippet: Would you buy a cheap PC with Google software that could only run Web programs, or would you stick with Microsoft Windows?
lead_paragraph: A year and half from now, you may see a new choice in the computer aisle of your local electronics store: little laptops, or netbooks, with an operating system made by Google instead of Microsoft. Google just announced that it will make a personal computer operating system, to be called Chrome OS, based on the Linux operating system. (It is separate from the company’s Android cellphone operating system, which also can work on netbooks.)

headline.main: Would You Miss Windows With a Google Operating System?

abstract: By giving away products like its new operating system, Google may be missing the opportunity to create a premium brand like that of Apple.
snippet: By giving away products like its new operating system, Google may be missing the opportunity to create a premium brand like that of Apple.
lead_paragraph: Is Google undercutting the value of its own brand by giving away everything free?

headline.main: Does Being Free Cheapen Google’s Brand?

abstract: Microsoft’s rechristened search engine, Bing, makes a concerted effort to organize search results in more helpful ways than Google, and often succeeds.
snippet: Microsoft’s rechristened search engine, Bing, makes a concerted effort to organize search results in more helpful ways than Google, and often succeeds.
lead_paragraph: For the last 15 years, Microsoft’s master business plan seems to have been, “Wait until somebody else has a hit. Then copy it.”

headline.main: Bing, the Imitator, Often Goes Google One Better
headline.print_headline: Bing Shifts The Game On Google
